Award.AwardTitle: Examining the macroevolutionary trajectories in Amoebozoa, a major lineage of eukaryotes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our current view of the eukaryotic Tree of Life suggests that life can be divided up into several major groups, including the Amoebozoa, the branch closest to our own major group, the Obazoa. The Amoebozoa is composed primarily of organisms that have single, amoeboid cells as part of their life cycles. Such cells are dynamic, changing shape as they move with transient extensions of the cell called pseudopodia. These cells are also used for engulfing prey. Amoebae are often thought to be simple because of their apparent lack of obvious characteristics. Consequently many biologists have the impression that these simple looking organisms are 'primitive' and assume that they are very similar to the first eukaryotes. Preliminary data suggest that there is more complexity and diversity in Amoebozoa than is generally acknowledged. This project is designed to find the relationships among amoebozoans and to develop ideas on how these various amoebae originated from an ancestor whose characteristics were reduced. Given that Amoebozoa is the closest lineage to our own, their ancestry and evolution is important to better understand how all eukaryotes evolved.

This research challenges the idea that amoebae are primitively simple. It uses synthetic studies that employ a whole life cycle approach using gene expression profiling and morphological data to address the patterns of broad scale evolution in this highly diverse major eukaryotic lineage. Although amoebozoans occur in nearly every environment, surprisingly little is known about their evolution. This is complicated by the fact that Amoebozoa is under represented in genomic-level databases, and although some recent progress has been made, much more is needed. This project will first develop a robust phylogenetic tree of Amoebozoa under a phylogenomic framework using RNAseq data from taxa broadly sampled across the breadth of the amoebozoan diversity. Additionally, for taxa that display complex life cycles researchers will examine gene expression profiles of various life stages using single cell RNA sequencing techniques. These data will identify commonalties among higher-level amoebozoan groups and by mapping character trait evolution on the tree of Amoebozoa, it will uncover the macroevolutionary trajectories of Amoebozoa. Moreover, this project will examine gene transfer events, gene innovations, gene family expansions and gene losses in Amoebozoa. This represents a unique opportunity to examine the evolution trajectory in which many of the taxa observed today evolved from complex ancestors to more 'simple' terminal taxa. The project will train undergraduate and graduate student training from underrepresented groups in genomics, phylogenetics and Amoebozoa biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbial eukaryotes are vastly diverse. They represent key taxa in nearly all global ecosystems, having important roles in nutrient cycling and in production. Amoebae are a typical life form across the breadth of the eukaryotes, and also represent a prevailing cell type in multicellular animals. Amoebozoa is a major eukaryotic lineage represents the sister group to the lineage that contains Fungi and animals. It consists of mostly amoeboid taxa, but considerable variation on this theme exists within the group. Taxa may be multicellular, produce fungal-like fruiting bodies, make flagellated cells, and make long lived resistant resting stages. Some taxa even wear hardened shells. This project aimed to holistically explore the evolutionary history of the Amoebozoa clade as a whole. Through deep sequencing and inference of tree of life for Amoebozoa, we have developed an intriguing set of hypotheses that suggest that the ancestor of Amoebozoa had a complex life cycle and a rich genomic makeup, but in most extant taxa these characters have been simplified. We have developed methodology to examine the developmental processes in amoeboid taxa through low input sequencing of the mRNA at discrete life stages. To better resolve the tree of life this project also was foundational in development of a software package that aids in phylogenomic dataset construction for eukaryotes as a whole.

This project supported the training of 21 participants including one minority high school, eleven undergraduate, and six graduate researchers, as well as two international visiting scholars and a postdoctoral scholar. These include international trainees who were integrally involved in this project, each having received their own funds from their home countries (Brazil, Spain, and Czech Republic) to come to Mississippi State University to participate in the project. The project directly resulted in 28 publications (24 peer-reviewed, 3 editorial-reviewed, and 1 in a popular science periodical), with an additional 3 in revision or under review. The project included a public outreach seminar directed to the general public as well as pre-K and K-2 public outreach workshops to illustrate the microbial diversity we encounter in our everyday lives. Findings which resulted from this project were presented internationally through 34 contributed presentations and 4 invited symposia at international meetings and congresses in Canada, Czech Republic, Italy, Russia, Spain, and Switzerland. This project yielded an extraordinary amount of sequence data from the breadth of amoeboid eukaryotic microbes. From these data we have unlocked several key questions in the evolutionary histories of these microbes.  Along the sequence data, a large culture collection stored in liquid nitrogen stasis was developed and is maintained as an important resource for future scientific discovery. Another key outcome of this project has been in software tool development, in which we created a software package called PhyloFisher that is broadly-useful, user-friendly software tool for sophisticated phylogenomic analyses of eukaryotes, which includes a pan-eukaryotic dataset for phylogenomics.
